Award.AwardTitle: Ionome to the Genome: Mapping the Gene Networks Controlling Nutrient Content in Rice Grain
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: David Salt (Purdue University)

CoPIs: Mary Lou Guerinot (Dartmouth University; subawardee), and Shannon Pinson (Texas A&M University; subawardee)

Senior Personnel: Lee Tarpley (Texas A&M University) and Min Zhang (Purdue University)

Mineral nutrients such as calcium, iron and zinc play important roles in human health. The development of rice varieties that produce grain with increased mineral nutrient contents and decreased levels of various toxic trace minerals could have a significant positive impact on human health, as food-based solutions to this hidden hunger offer sustainable solutions to these problems of malnutrition. This project will leverage work done in model systems and use high throughput elemental analysis, genomics, rice breeding and bioinformatics to uncover the genes and gene networks that regulate the mineral composition of rice grain. As a starting point, the project will take advantage of and explore the natural variation that exists in rice grain mineral content in the many thousands of rice varieties grown throughout the world. The rice grain ionomic data, DNA microarray genotyping, transcript profiling and mapping data, and QTL information generated will be made available via the web-based Purdue Ionomics Information Management System (PiiMS) (www.purdue.edu/dp/ionomics/), Gramene (http://www.gramene.org/) and Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/).

The broader impacts of this project will include contributing to increasing bio-available mineral nutrients in plants, and to solving important problems in human health. If successful, nutrient-rich seed should also lead to agronomic benefits such as increased seedling vigor, resistance to disease and other stresses, and increased crop yields. Furthermore, understanding the pathways by which toxic metals accumulate in plants will enable the development of crops to exclude toxic metals and create healthier food sources, or to extract toxic metals from the soil as a strategy to clean up polluted lands and water. Educational outreach will include training of postdoctoral fellows, undergraduates and graduate students in the field of ionomics. Public outreach efforts will also include contributions to science museums through a genomics exhibit which is currently under development (www.genomicsexplorer.com).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: With about half of the world’s human population dependent on rice as a staple food, rice provides the majority of dietary nutrients to billions of people. For these people rice is not just an important source of energy, but also of essential minerals such as iron, calcium and zinc. Unfortunately, rice does not contain large amounts of minerals, and as a result mineral nutrient deficiencies are common among people dependent on rice as their major food. On the other hand, toxic elements such as arsenic and cadmium, which can be present in farmer’s fields naturally or as pollutants, can accumulate in rice. Such rice, and food products made from it, can be harmful if consumed in large amounts. Additionally, certain minerals that accumulate in the rice grain, although not important for human health, are important for the health and vigour of young rice seedlings as they rely on the rice grain as an important source of mineral nutrients during their early growth. The development of new varieties of rice with both increased amounts of beneficial mineral nutrients, and reduced amount of toxic elements, therefore offers a practical solution to help improve the health of people through improved diets and healthier rice crops.

 

The first step toward breeding new rice varieties with improved mineral content is to understand the variation in the mineral content of the current rice available to the plant breeders whose job it is to develop new varieties of rice. In this project, we assessed the mineral content of rice grain from almost two thousand different varieties of rice collected worldwide and maintained as a collection by the US Department of Agriculture. Rice breeders can now make use of this publically available information that we developed to select rice varieties with the required mineral content, such as high iron or low cadmium for their breeding programs. However, to develop a new rice variety that can be grown by farmers, rice breeders need to combine these desirable mineral content characteristics with other important agricultural features such as high yield and resistance to disease. To speed up this breeding process, our project has focused on identifying regions within the chromosomes of rice that control its mineral content and we have identified over 130 such regions. This genetic information can now be used as a molecular tag to help breeders identify which of their thousands of plant breeding offspring are most likely to have the desired improvements in grain mineral content. This saves breeders from the costly and time-consuming analysis of grain samples from their many thousands of plants, and allows them to determine, even before seeds are set, which ones to cross again in order to speed the combination of desired agricultural characteristics with desired grain mineral content. Furthermore, this genetic information can also be used to develop breeding approaches that incorporate the direct introduction of rice genes from one rice variety into another. This will further accelerate the breeding process and help develop the many rice varieties required for adaptation and production in the variable growth conditions around the world, and that can also deliver grain with a high mineral nutrient content and with low levels of contaminating toxic elements for improved human health.
